p.seg: That by means of which humans differ from wild birds and beasts
is quite rarefied:
the common people distance themselves from this,
and the true gentleman treasures it.
Shun was clear about the various creatures in the world,
and he had studied the moral principles for men:
he acted out of benevolence and righteousness,
but it is not as if he was setting out to implement benevolence and righteousness (he was concerned with good governance. ) See 郭店語叢1 孝不可為).
When, as one seeks something one gets it
and when one discards something one has it no more
in such a case seeking is (directly) conducive to the getting;
and that is because one is seeking is what is within oneself.
[However,] when for seeking something there is a Way,
but the obtaining of it is in the hands of fate,
in such a case the seeking is not (directly) conducive the getting,
and that is because one is seeking what is outside one.
There are cases where someone is by nature (irremediably) good,
and there are other cases where someone is by nature (irremediably) wicked,
and that is why, with Yao as the ruler, there was (such a bad person as) Xiang,

and with Zhou as an elder brother's son
and as their ruler (respectively)
there were (such fine people as) Wei Ziqi and Royal Prince Bi Gan.

The true gentleman achieves his deep effects (on others) by means of the Way. [Compare the pregnant use of 之 in 學而時習之。]

when in staying with it they find peace he (the true gentleman) helps them to a deepened understanding;
and when he helps them to a deepened understanding, then as they opt for things they come upon the sources (within themselves) left right (and centre!).
